title: Ezekiel Chapter 31 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 31 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 31 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 31.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 31:2, to whom is the Son of man commanded to speak?
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh king of Egypt
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:2 instructs the Son of man to speak unto Pharaoh king of Egypt and to his multitude.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 31:3, the Assyrian is compared to which type of tree?
questions.correctAnswer: Cedar in Lebanon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:3 describes the Assyrian as a cedar in Lebanon with fair branches and a high stature.

questions.question: What made the cedar (Assyrian) great, according to Ezekiel 31:4?
options: The waters and rivers around it
questions.correctAnswer: The waters and rivers around it
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:4 states that the waters made him great, the deep set him on high, with rivers running around his plants.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 31:7, the root of the cedar was by small streams.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:7 says the root was by great waters, not small streams.

questions.question: What did all the fowls of heaven do in Ezekiel 31:6?
options: Made their nests in his boughs
questions.correctAnswer: Made their nests in his boughs
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:6 states that all the fowls of heaven made their nests in the cedar’s boughs.

questions.question: What did the trees of Eden do according to Ezekiel 31:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Envied the cedar
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:9 states that all the trees of Eden envied the cedar because of the multitude of his branches.

questions.question: Who was given power over the cedar because of its wickedness in Ezekiel 31:11?
options: The mighty one of the heathen
questions.correctAnswer: The mighty one of the heathen
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:11 says that the mighty one of the heathen would deal with the cedar because of its wickedness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Ezekiel 31:12: 'His branches are fallen, and his boughs are broken by all the ______ of the land.'
questions.correctAnswer: rivers
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:12 clearly states that his boughs are broken by all the rivers of the land.

questions.question: What remains upon the cedar’s ruin according to Ezekiel 31:13?
options: All the fowls of heaven and beasts of the field
questions.correctAnswer: All the fowls of heaven and beasts of the field
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:13 says upon his ruin shall all the fowls of heaven remain, as well as all the beasts of the field.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 31:14 says that trees by the waters will be exalted above all others.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:14 warns that none of the trees by the waters shall exalt themselves for their height; all are delivered to death.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 31:15, who mourned for the cedar when it went down to the grave?
options: Lebanon and all the trees of the field
questions.correctAnswer: Lebanon and all the trees of the field
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:15 states that Lebanon and all the trees of the field fainted and mourned for the cedar.

questions.question: What caused the nations to shake according to Ezekiel 31:16?
options: The sound of the cedar’s fall
questions.correctAnswer: The sound of the cedar’s fall
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:16 says the nations shook at the sound of the cedar’s fall when it was cast down to hell.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 31:17, who went down into hell with the cedar?
options: Those slain with the sword and his arm
questions.correctAnswer: Those slain with the sword and his arm
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:17 states that those slain with the sword and those that were his arm went down into hell with him.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 31:18 says Pharaoh and his multitude shall lie among the uncircumcised with those slain by the sword.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:18 explains that Pharaoh and all his multitude shall lie in the midst of the uncircumcised with those slain by the sword.

questions.question: What is Pharaoh compared to in Ezekiel 31:18?
questions.correctAnswer: A tree of Eden
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:18 compares Pharaoh to a tree of Eden in glory and greatness before stating his downfall.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 31 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 31 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is proud of their achievements and feels superior to others. Based on Ezekiel 31, what biblical truth would you share about humility?
options: Pride leads to being brought down and judged by God
Pride is a sign of spiritual growth and blessing
God rewards those who exalt themselves
Humility is not important in Christian life
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to being brought down and judged by God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:10-11 teaches that lifting oneself up in pride leads to being delivered into the hands of judgment for wickedness, showing the importance of humility. Verses 14 and 18 also illustrate that exaltation leads to downfall.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 31 illustrate the importance of trusting in God rather than worldly greatness?
options: Worldly greatness is temporary and leads to ruin
Trusting in worldly power guarantees success
God favors those with the greatest wealth
Physical strength is the ultimate measure of blessing
questions.correctAnswer: Worldly greatness is temporary and leads to ruin
questions.explanation: The chapter describes the Assyrian as a great tree brought down despite its height (Ezekiel 31:3-12), teaching that trusting in worldly greatness is futile compared to reliance on God. Verses 15-17 emphasize mourning over the fall, highlighting its certainty.

questions.question: In the context of Ezekiel 31, how should a Christian respond when facing trials or setbacks?
options: Trust God’s sovereignty and remain humble
Give up because God has rejected you
Seek to exalt yourself to overcome hardships
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God’s sovereignty and remain humble
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:15-16 shows that God controls the rise and fall of nations and causes mourning at their downfall, teaching believers to trust God’s sovereignty and maintain humility during trials.

questions.question: What lesson about pride and downfall can be drawn from the imagery of the great cedar in Lebanon in Ezekiel 31?
options: Exalting oneself leads to a fall and destruction
The tallest trees are always the strongest
questions.correctAnswer: Exalting oneself leads to a fall and destruction
questions.explanation: The cedar represents the Assyrian who was exalted but was cut down because of pride (Ezekiel 31:5-12). This symbolizes that pride leads to judgment and downfall.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 31, what is the significance of the waters that made the cedar great?
options: They represent sources of strength and blessing
They are a symbol of weakness
They are meaningless in the tree's growth
questions.correctAnswer: They represent sources of strength and blessing
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:4-7 describes how waters helped the cedar grow tall and strong, symbolizing blessings and resources that enable growth, yet even such strength can lead to pride and downfall if misused.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 31 teach about the consequences of wickedness?
options: Wickedness leads to being delivered into the hands of enemies
Wickedness only affects others, not oneself
questions.correctAnswer: Wickedness leads to being delivered into the hands of enemies
questions.explanation: Verse 11 states God delivered the proud cedar into the hands of a mighty nation because of wickedness, teaching that sin leads to judgment and consequences.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged after suffering loss of position or influence. Based on Ezekiel 31, what encouragement can you offer about God’s plan?
options: God controls the rise and fall and will comfort His people
Loss means God has abandoned you
Only the strong survive in God's kingdom
Position is the most important spiritual indicator
questions.correctAnswer: God controls the rise and fall and will comfort His people
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:16-17 shows God causing nations to shake at the fall but also comforting the trees of Eden, symbolizing His care for His people despite their trials.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 31 teaches that exaltation leads to spiritual blessing and protection from all harm.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The chapter warns that exaltation leads to downfall and judgment (Ezekiel 31:10-12), not guaranteed blessing or protection.

questions.question: True or False: The imagery of the great tree in Ezekiel 31 encourages believers to avoid pride and remain humble before God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The chapter uses the cedar's pride and downfall to teach the dangers of pride and the value of humility (Ezekiel 31:5-11).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 31 teach about the importance of spiritual vigilance and avoiding self-exaltation in leadership roles?
options: Leaders who exalt themselves face judgment and ruin
Leaders should seek to be the tallest and strongest
God ignores the pride of leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders who exalt themselves face judgment and ruin
questions.explanation: Verses 10-12 warn that lifting oneself up in pride results in being handed over to enemies and judgment, a warning for leaders to remain humble.

questions.question: What practical lesson about stewardship and using God's blessings can be learned from the great tree's downfall in Ezekiel 31?
options: Blessings must be used humbly and not for pride
Using blessings for self-glory is encouraged
Blessings are irrelevant to spiritual life
questions.correctAnswer: Blessings must be used humbly and not for pride
questions.explanation: The cedar was blessed with water and growth but fell due to pride (Ezekiel 31:4-11), teaching believers to steward blessings humbly.

questions.question: Based on Ezekiel 31, what biblical principle can be applied to family life regarding humility and pride?
options: Humility fosters peace, while pride can cause downfall
Humility is not relevant to family relationships
Pride is encouraged to show strength
questions.correctAnswer: Humility fosters peace, while pride can cause downfall
questions.explanation: The chapter's theme of pride leading to destruction (Ezekiel 31:10-12) applies to family life, encouraging humility for harmony and longevity.

questions.question: A church member struggles with envy towards others’ success. What teaching from Ezekiel 31 could help them overcome this?
options: Envy the humble, not the proud, because pride leads to ruin
Comparison is the key to spiritual growth
questions.correctAnswer: Envy the humble, not the proud, because pride leads to ruin
questions.explanation: Verses 9 and 18 show that the proud cedar was envied but ultimately fell, teaching that prideful success is unstable and humility is more worthy of respect.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 31 compares Pharaoh's greatness to a tree that was once __________ but ultimately brought down because of pride.
questions.correctAnswer: exalted
questions.explanation: The chapter repeatedly describes the tree as exalted in height and branches but brought down due to pride (Ezekiel 31:5, 10).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 31 encourage believers to practice perseverance through trials?
options: By trusting God’s ultimate justice despite current hardships
By giving up when faced with difficulties
By relying solely on personal strength
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting God’s ultimate justice despite current hardships
questions.explanation: The chapter shows God’s control over rise and fall (Ezekiel 31:15-17) encouraging believers to trust in His justice and remain steadfast.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 31 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 31.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 31, the Assyrian is compared to which type of tree, symbolizing his greatness and stature?
questions.correctAnswer: Cedar in Lebanon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:3 explicitly states that the Assyrian was a cedar in Lebanon with fair branches and high stature, symbolizing his greatness.

questions.question: What is the significance of 'waters' in Ezekiel 31 that caused the Assyrian tree to grow tall and strong?
options: The deep and rivers surrounding the tree
questions.correctAnswer: The deep and rivers surrounding the tree
questions.explanation: Verse 4 describes how waters, the deep, and rivers running around the plants nourished the Assyrian cedar, making it great and tall.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 31, which groups are said to have made their nests and brought forth young under the branches of the Assyrian cedar?
options: Fowls of heaven and beasts of the field
questions.correctAnswer: Fowls of heaven and beasts of the field
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:6 states that all the fowls of heaven nested in his boughs and all the beasts of the field brought forth their young under his branches.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Ezekiel 31 when describing Pharaoh’s greatness as a towering tree?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The chapter uses a simile comparing Assyria (and by extension Pharaoh) to a cedar tree, a common Near Eastern symbol of strength and majesty (Ezekiel 31:2-3).

questions.question: Ezekiel 31:8 states that no tree in the garden of God was like the Assyrian cedar in what aspect?
questions.correctAnswer: Beauty
questions.explanation: Verse 8 highlights the cedar’s unmatched beauty compared to the cedars, firs, and chestnuts in the garden of God.

questions.question: The downfall of the Assyrian cedar in Ezekiel 31 is attributed to what cause?
questions.correctAnswer: Wickedness and pride
questions.explanation: Verse 11 states God delivered him into the hands of the mighty for his wickedness and because he lifted himself up in height (pride).

questions.question: Which phrase in Ezekiel 31 illustrates the theme of divine judgment on pride and arrogance?
options: 'Because thou hast lifted up thyself in height'
'All the fowls of heaven made their nests'
'I caused Lebanon to mourn for him'
questions.correctAnswer: 'Because thou hast lifted up thyself in height'
questions.explanation: Verse 10 explicitly connects the cedar’s pride in height to the reason for divine judgment.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 31 uses the imagery of trees to foreshadow the fate of nations who exalt themselves above God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The chapter uses the image of the lofty cedar cut down to illustrate how nations that exalt themselves will be brought low (Ezekiel 31:14).

questions.question: Which other biblical book contains a similar imagery of a great tree symbolizing a mighty king or nation, as seen in Ezekiel 31?
questions.correctAnswer: Daniel
questions.explanation: Daniel 4 uses the image of a great tree representing a king’s pride and downfall, paralleling Ezekiel’s use of the cedar as a symbol of Assyria/Egypt.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'all the trees of Eden' in Ezekiel 31:9 and 16 within the context of the chapter?
options: They represent other nations envying or mourning the downfall of the mighty
They symbolize the Garden of Eden’s literal flora
questions.correctAnswer: They represent other nations envying or mourning the downfall of the mighty
questions.explanation: 'All the trees of Eden' metaphorically refers to other great nations or powers that envied the Assyrian cedar’s greatness and later mourned its fall (Ezekiel 31:9,16).

questions.question: In Ezekiel 31:15, what natural element is said to mourn the downfall of the cedar?
options: Lebanon and all the trees of the field
questions.correctAnswer: Lebanon and all the trees of the field
questions.explanation: Verse 15 describes Lebanon and all the trees fainting and mourning for the cedar’s fall, illustrating cosmic sorrow over the demise of the mighty.

questions.question: The phrase 'I caused the nations to shake at the sound of his fall' in Ezekiel 31:16 serves what rhetorical function?
options: It emphasizes the widespread impact of the Assyrian’s downfall
It references a specific historical battle
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the widespread impact of the Assyrian’s downfall
questions.explanation: The phrase uses hyperbole to highlight how the fall of a great power caused fear and trembling among nations (Ezekiel 31:16).

questions.question: Which phrase in Ezekiel 31 foreshadows the ultimate judgment and burial of Pharaoh and his multitude among the uncircumcised and slain by the sword?
options: 'Thou shalt be brought down with the trees of Eden unto the nether parts of the earth'
'All the people of the earth are gone down from his shadow'
'I have delivered him into the hand of the mighty one of the heathen'
questions.correctAnswer: 'Thou shalt be brought down with the trees of Eden unto the nether parts of the earth'
questions.explanation: Verse 18 prophesies Pharaoh’s ultimate fate being cast down with the trees of Eden into the nether parts of the earth among the uncircumcised and slain.

questions.question: Ezekiel 31 uses the image of the 'nether parts of the earth' multiple times. What concept does this phrase primarily convey in the ancient Hebrew context?
options: Sheol or the realm of the dead
questions.correctAnswer: Sheol or the realm of the dead
questions.explanation: The 'nether parts of the earth' is a Hebrew idiom for Sheol, the abode of the dead or the grave (Ezekiel 31:14,16,18).

questions.question: What is the implied authorial intent in addressing Pharaoh as being like the great cedar in Ezekiel 31:2?
options: To warn Egypt of pride leading to downfall
To illustrate Pharaoh’s fertility and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: To warn Egypt of pride leading to downfall
questions.explanation: The comparison serves as a prophetic warning that Pharaoh’s greatness and pride will lead to judgment and destruction (Ezekiel 31:2-11).

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 31 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 31 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: To whom is Ezekiel commanded to speak in Ezekiel 31?
options: Pharaoh king of Egypt and his multitude
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh king of Egypt and his multitude
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:2 explicitly directs Ezekiel to speak to Pharaoh king of Egypt and his multitude. This highlights God's sovereign communication to earthly rulers, consistent with God's word to Nebuchadnezzar (Daniel 4:17) and to kings like Saul (1 Samuel 15:10-11).

questions.question: In Ezekiel 31, the Assyrian is compared to what kind of tree?
questions.correctAnswer: A cedar in Lebanon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:3 compares the Assyrian to a cedar in Lebanon, symbolizing majesty and strength. The cedar is a biblical symbol of greatness and God's provision (Psalm 92:12; Song of Solomon 5:15).

questions.question: What caused the Assyrian tree to grow tall and have many branches according to Ezekiel 31?
options: The waters and rivers surrounding it
questions.correctAnswer: The waters and rivers surrounding it
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:4-5 explains that the waters and rivers made the tree great and caused its height and branches to multiply. This imagery reflects God's providential care, similar to how Psalm 1:3 describes a righteous person flourishing by streams of water.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 31, what dwelt under the shadow of the Assyrian tree?
options: Only the birds of the air
The wild animals of the desert
questions.correctAnswer: All great nations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:6 states that under the tree's shadow dwelt all great nations, symbolizing political power and influence. This reflects biblical themes of God's judgment on nations that exalt themselves (Daniel 4:20-22; Psalm 2:1-4).

questions.question: What was the reaction of the other trees of Eden to the Assyrian tree's greatness?
questions.correctAnswer: They envied him
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:9 says all the trees of Eden envied the Assyrian tree for its multitude of branches and beauty. This reflects the biblical motif of pride and envy leading to downfall (Proverbs 27:4; James 3:14-16).

questions.question: Why does God say He delivered the Assyrian tree into the hand of the mighty one of the heathen?
options: Because of his wickedness and pride
Because he was weak and humble
questions.correctAnswer: Because of his wickedness and pride
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:10-11 explains that God delivered the tree into the hand of the mighty because it lifted itself up in pride and wickedness. This aligns with biblical teaching on God's judgment of the proud (Proverbs 16:18; Isaiah 2:12).

questions.question: What happened to the Assyrian tree after God’s judgment?
options: It was cut off and left broken
It was transplanted to a new land
questions.correctAnswer: It was cut off and left broken
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:12 describes how strangers cut off the tree, left its branches fallen and broken. This illustrates the certainty of divine judgment on prideful powers (Jeremiah 51:33; Nahum 1:12).

questions.question: What is the fate of all trees by the waters, as declared by God in Ezekiel 31:14?
options: They are all delivered unto death and the nether parts of the earth
They will be transplanted to a garden
questions.correctAnswer: They are all delivered unto death and the nether parts of the earth
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:14 states that none of the trees by the waters shall exalt themselves; all are delivered unto death, symbolizing universal judgment and mortality (Ecclesiastes 3:18-21; Hebrews 9:27).

questions.question: How did God respond on the day the Assyrian tree went down to the grave?
options: God caused mourning and restrained the floods
God rejoiced and lifted the tree
questions.correctAnswer: God caused mourning and restrained the floods
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:15 describes God causing mourning and restraining floods when the tree fell, showing God's sovereign control over creation and judgment (Psalm 46:4-5; Jonah 1:15).

questions.question: What effect did the fall of the Assyrian tree have on the nations and the trees of Eden?
options: The nations shook and the trees fainted
The nations rejoiced and the trees grew taller
The nations were indifferent and the trees flourished
The nations mourned but the trees were unaffected
questions.correctAnswer: The nations shook and the trees fainted
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:16 shows that the nations shook at the fall, and the trees fainted, symbolizing the cosmic impact of divine judgment (Isaiah 2:19-21; Revelation 6:12-14).

questions.question: Who went down into hell with the Assyrian tree according to Ezekiel 31?
options: Those slain by the sword and those who dwelt under his shadow
questions.correctAnswer: Those slain by the sword and those who dwelt under his shadow
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:17 states that those slain by the sword and those who were the Assyrian’s arm went down into hell with him, illustrating corporate judgment (Psalm 49:14-15; Ezekiel 32:21).

questions.question: In Ezekiel 31, what is Pharaoh and his multitude likened to in glory and greatness?
questions.correctAnswer: The trees of Eden
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31:18 compares Pharaoh and his multitude to the trees of Eden in glory and greatness, but they too will be brought down, reflecting the theme of pride before a fall (Proverbs 16:18; Daniel 4:37).

questions.question: What attribute of God is demonstrated by delivering the Assyrian tree into the hand of the heathen as in Ezekiel 31?
questions.correctAnswer: God's justice and sovereignty
questions.explanation: Delivering the Assyrian into the hand of the heathen for his wickedness (Ezekiel 31:11) shows God's just judgment and sovereign control over nations, consistent with Romans 13:1-4 and Psalm 75:7.

questions.question: What theological truth is taught by the imagery of the Assyrian tree being cut down and its branches broken?
options: The downfall of prideful earthly powers by divine judgment
The eternal flourishing of all kingdoms
The unchanging power of human empires
questions.correctAnswer: The downfall of prideful earthly powers by divine judgment
questions.explanation: The cutting down of the tree (Ezekiel 31:12) symbolizes God's judgment on prideful powers, affirming the biblical doctrine that God opposes the proud (James 4:6; Isaiah 14:12-15).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 31 contribute to biblical eschatology?
options: It illustrates the ultimate judgment and downfall of proud nations and rulers
It promises the eternal reign of Pharaoh
It predicts the everlasting flourishing of Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates the ultimate judgment and downfall of proud nations and rulers
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 31 portrays the downfall of the Assyrian and Pharaoh as a future certainty, reflecting eschatological themes of judgment (Daniel 7:26; Revelation 20:11-15).
